pages.title: About
pages.content:
The Photographer

With over a decade behind the lens, I've dedicated my career to finding beauty in the overlooked — the interplay of shadow and light, the quiet drama of everyday moments, and the raw emotion of human connection.

My work spans editorial portraiture, fine art landscapes, and documentary projects across five continents. Each frame is guided by a simple philosophy: show the world as it deserves to be seen.

Approach

I work primarily with natural light, preferring the honesty it brings to every subject. Whether it's a portrait session in a dimly lit studio or a landscape shoot at golden hour, I chase the moments that feel both fleeting and eternal.

Every project begins with a conversation — understanding your vision, your story, the emotion you want to convey. From there, I disappear behind the camera and let the magic happen.

Recognition

Featured in The Guardian, National Geographic Traveller, British Journal of Photography, and Vogue Italia. Winner of the Sony World Photography Award (Open Category, 2023).

articles.title: Chiaroscuro — A Portrait Series
articles.content:
This series explores the Renaissance technique of chiaroscuro — the dramatic interplay of light and dark — applied to contemporary portraiture.

Shot over six months in a converted warehouse studio, each subject was lit using a single source: sometimes a bare bulb, sometimes filtered daylight through industrial windows. The goal was to strip away everything except the essential relationship between the human face and light itself.

The results speak to something timeless. Without colour, without context, what remains is expression — the architecture of a face revealed through shadow.

"In darkness, we find what light alone cannot reveal."

The series was exhibited at The Photographers' Gallery, London, and published in the British Journal of Photography's annual edition.

articles.title: Between Tides — Seascape Studies
articles.content:
The coast at dusk holds a particular kind of silence. It's not the absence of sound — the waves are always there — but a quieting of the mind that comes from watching the horizon dissolve into colour.

This ongoing project documents the coastlines of Portugal, Iceland, and western Scotland during the golden and blue hours. Using long exposures and minimal post-processing, these images aim to capture the meditative quality of the sea at its most still.

Each frame required patience: sometimes hours of waiting for the right cloud formation, the right swell, the right quality of light. Photography as meditation.

"The sea is everything. It covers seven-tenths of the terrestrial globe."

Selected images from this series are available as limited edition prints.

articles.title: Still — Minimal Interiors
articles.content:
There's a quiet beauty in the spaces we inhabit. This series turns the lens inward — literally — documenting interiors stripped to their essence. A chair by a window. A plant reaching toward light. The geometry of a staircase.

Shot in homes, studios, and galleries across Scandinavia and Japan, these images celebrate the philosophy of 'less as more.' Every object in frame is there for a reason; every negative space serves the composition.

The palette is deliberately restrained: whites, creams, pale wood, the occasional dark accent. It's photography that whispers rather than shouts.

Inspired by the Japanese concept of ma (間) — the meaningful space between things — this work invites the viewer to slow down and find beauty in simplicity.
articles.seo_description: Minimal interior photography celebrating quiet beauty and the spaces between things.

articles.title: Form & Function — Architectural Studies
articles.content:
Architecture is frozen music, and photographing it is about finding the rhythm. This project examines modernist and contemporary buildings through an abstract lens — reducing structures to their fundamental elements of line, form, light, and shadow.

From the brutalist concrete of London's Barbican to the sleek glass of Basel's Novartis campus, each image isolates a detail that reveals something about the building's character. A corner. A reflection. The way light falls across a facade at a specific time of day.

These aren't architectural photographs in the traditional sense — there are no establishing shots, no context. Instead, they're meditations on geometry and the human impulse to impose order on space.

"Architecture is the learned game, correct and magnificent, of forms assembled in the light."
— Le Corbusier

Commissioned by Architectural Digest and exhibited at the Swiss Architecture Museum, Basel.

articles.seo_description: Abstract architectural photography — modernist buildings reduced to line, form, and light.
